theurgy definition: the art or technique of compelling or persuading a god or beneficent or supernatural power to do or refrain from doing something.

Theurgy (from Greek θεουργία) describes the practice of rituals, sometimes seen as magical in nature,  performed with the intention of invoking the action or evoking the presence of one or more gods, especially with the goal of uniting with the divine, achieving henosis, and perfecting oneself.
Henosis - Henosis is the word for mystical "oneness," "union," or "unity" in classical Greek.
Julian the Apostate - Julian, also known as Julian the Apostate, as well as Julian the Philosopher, was Roman Emperor from 361 to 363 and a noted philosopher and Greek writer.

Theurgy (from Greek θεουργία) describes the practice of rituals, sometimes seen as magical in nature,  performed with the intention of invoking the action or evoking the presence of one or more gods, especially with the goal of uniting with the divine, achieving henosis, and perfecting oneself.

wiki.text:
'Theurgy' (from Greek θεουργία) describes the practice of rituals, sometimes
seen as magical in nature, performed with the intention of invoking the action
or evoking the presence of one or more gods, especially with the goal of uniting
with the divine, achieving henosis, and perfecting oneself.
wiki.title: theurgy
